Award.AwardTitle: Investigating Conceptual Foundations for a Transdisciplinary Model Integrating Computer Science into the Elementary STEM Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Computing has become an integral part of the practice of in modern science, technology engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. As a result, the STEM+Computing Partnership (STEM+C) program seeks to integrate the use of computational approaches in K-12 STEM teaching and learning and understand how this integration can improve STEM learning, engagement, and persistence. Computational Thinking (CT) is a relatively new educational focus and a clear need for learners as a 21st century skill. This prokect will address this challenging new area for young learners, an area greatly in need of research and learning materials. Broward County Schools' literacy and curriculum coordinator team will work with their staff and teachers to develop Problem Based Learning (PBL) integrated Computer Science (CS) and science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) modules, and professional development materials around these modules. A University of Chicago research team will conduct strong research studies to evaluate the effectiveness of these materials and what contributes to that effectiveness. The collaboration with the well known non profit Code.org leads to strong potential for wide dissemination of materials, as the Code.org site is used very frequently by teachers and after-school/informal educators to obtain instructional materials.

In a partnership between Broward County Public Schools (FL), researchers at the University of Chicago, and Code.org, the Principal Investigators propose to integrate Computer Science (CS) and science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) at the grade 3-5 level within the literacy block of the school day. This period is when the science curriculum is covered, in units that currently cover integrated content in science, technology, engineering and mathematics. They plan to add 6 Problem Based Learning (PBL) units to this curriculum that integrate CS and STEM. They will reach 84 grade 3 - 5 classrooms at 14 schools. They will pilot the modules 14 schools, and later, conduct an efficacy trial with approximately 84 teachers and 1680 students in each condition (modules, no modules). They will measure both achievement and attitudes towards STEM and CS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computer science (CS) is increasingly warranting more attention for inclusion in the public school curriculum. While most computer science education work has focused on the high school level, some literature suggests that in order to have a strong foundation in CS, it may be important to start early, at the elementary level. However, bringing computer science to the elementary school day is not a small task. Typically, elementary schools place a strong emphasis on literacy and mathematics instruction leaving little time for all of the other subjects (e.g. science, social studies, art) including computer science. This project addressed this challenge.

Outlier Research & Evaluation at the University of Chicago and Broward County Public Schools collaborated on this work as a research-practice partnership.This means practitioners and researchers worked as a single team with everyone providing input into all aspects of the work. Together, we devised a strategy that entailed leveraging the time in the school day already devoted to literacy. Specifically, we created six cross-disciplinary problem-based units, two each for grades 3, 4, and 5. The units align with Florida?s English Language Arts (ELA), science, social studies and computer science standards. Each has a storyline focused on a problem that leads students through the lessons in an integrated way.

Instructional Facilitators in Broward County provided professional development through workshops, lesson modeling and coaching for the teachers. The teachers provided feedback on implementation successes and challenges that were valuable in creating coherent Time4CS modules, aligned to the curriculum and ready for broader dissemination.

The intellectual merit of the work emerged primarily from two main research questions:

1)How is implementation of the Time4CS modules associated with grade 3-5 students' academic achievement outcomes?

 2) How is implementation of the Time4CS modules associated with students' attitudes toward computer science?

To briefly describe the study design, we used an approach that included randomly assigning schools to treatment and comparison groups. As for measuring implementation of the modules, we did so in three ways:  1) module use or not; 2) amount of student exposure to computer science instruction; and 3) presence of particular teaching strategies. We collected attitudinal data (about CS and school in general) by administering questionnaires to all participating students and our academic outcomes included the Florida State Assessment (FSA) tests in ELA, mathematics, and science. We also used the Achieve3000 determined Lexile level as an additional literacy measure.

The study had several important findings. First, we found that students' attitudes and academic achievement outcomes did not differ based on whether their teachers taught Time4CS modules. However, it is worth noting that teachers who taught Time4CS modules taught more CS than teachers who did not. We also found that non-grade-level assigned CS lessons were associated with higher academic achievement scores on ELA and mathematics standardized tests. Similarly, higher amounts of interdisciplinary teaching practices were associated with higher student academic achievement outcomes.  

We also explored whether using the Time4CS modules could help reduce gaps between groups of students who have been historically underrepresented in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) and computer science (CS) (e.g., African Americans, girls, students from lower socioeconomic status [SES] backgrounds).  We got mixed results. For example, we found that Asian students scored even higher (compared to White students) on the FSA science test when their teachers provided them with opportunities to engage in interdisciplinary work. In contrast, completing Time4CS modules and exposure to the teaching practices assessed in this study did not help close gaps in FSA science between male and female students. Girls still had lower scores.

The Time4CS project is generating broad impacts through sharing the Time4CS modules. This project has led to further collaboration with Code.org to disseminate the modules within their platform, potentially reaching a large international audience of educators. Additionally, in the face of high stakes testing and competition for time in the elementary school day, many educators struggle with ways to bring computer science (and science) to young learners. The findings of this project illuminates ways to do so such that more young learners, particularly those in underrepresented groups, have opportunities to engage in these STEM subjects.
